G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters of custody, visitation, and support pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as the original judgment was entered in this Court.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; Supplemental Probate Court Rule 412)

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters of custody, visitation, and support pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as the original judgment was entered in this Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 & 31.proposition: The child’s best interests are the paramount concern in all custody determinations under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 31, and G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a).

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10(a).proposition: The child’s best interests are the paramount concern in all custody determinations under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 & 31, and G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a).

M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: See also M.G.L. c. 208, § 31A (considering parental relocation and its impact).

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: The controlling standards have been set forth in Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985) (best interests require balancing stability against the child’s welfare following changed circumstances), and Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996) (modification proper where new developments adversely affect child’s welfare).
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: Yannas does set out controlling standards, but they are specific to removal of children from the Commonwealth after a custody award. The opinion frames the ‘best interests’ analysis in that context, focusing on the custodial parent’s ‘real advantage’ and the impact on the child, not on modification of custody orders following changed circumstances or on balancing stability versus welfare in a post‑judgment modification sense. The second half of the proposition (modification proper where new developments adversely affect welfare) comes from Custody of Vaughn, not from Yannas, and Yannas itself is not about modification standards at all.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life)….”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The controlling standards have been set forth in Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985) (best interests require balancing stability against the child’s welfare following changed circumstances), and Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996) (modification proper where new developments adversely affect child’s welfare).
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: Custody of Vaughn is an initial custody determination and an appellate remand for further findings regarding domestic violence, not a modification case. The court does not discuss standards for modifying a prior custody order based on new developments or changed circumstances; rather, it directs the trial judge to make explicit findings on domestic violence and its effect on the child within the existing best‑interests framework. Thus, it does not stand for the proposition that modification is proper where new developments adversely affect the child’s welfare.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.”

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that relocation or substantial change in the parties’ living situations constitutes a material change when it affects the child’s routine, education, or stability.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion addresses relocation and the best-interests standard, but it does not frame relocation or substantial living-changes as a "material change" in circumstances in the sense used for modification of custody or parenting plans. Instead, it applies G.L. c. 208, § 30’s “cause shown” standard and focuses on whether the proposed move is in the children’s best interests, without articulating a general rule that relocation itself constitutes a material change whenever it affects routine, education, or stability. The cited ALI Principles excerpt mentions relocation as a substantial change, but that is secondary authority, not a Massachusetts holding that courts "consistently" treat such moves as material changes.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]…’”}

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that relocation or substantial change in the parties’ living situations constitutes a material change when it affects the child’s routine, education, or stability.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly rejects treating the custodial parent’s relocation or the resulting change in living arrangements as a material and substantial change justifying custody modification. The court holds that a request for relocation is distinct from a request to modify custody and must be supported by a material change in circumstances other than the move itself. While the opinion discusses stability and routine, it does so to emphasize that the temporary, relocation-driven change in the child’s living situation cannot be used as the material change required for modification.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28… The probate judge found… ‘[b]ecause Caleb spends the majority of his week in Northboro… most of his activities take place there.’ This was a change in Caleb’s living arrangements brought about solely as a consequence of the mother’s compliance with the August 25 order… [and] cannot form the basis upon which a final judgment modifying custody is granted.”}```урнал

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently hold that relocation or substantial change in the parties’ living situations constitutes a material change when it affects the child’s routine, education, or stability.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: Hale v. Hale addresses standards for allowing a custodial parent to relocate children out of Massachusetts and emphasizes that the decision must turn on the children’s best interests, including the welfare of the custodial parent and potential changes to visitation. It does not discuss ‘material change’ in the sense of a change-of-custody or modification standard, nor does it hold that relocation or substantial changes in living situations are, by themselves, a material change. The case is about the proper factors in an initial/standalone removal decision, not about what constitutes a material change in circumstances warranting modification.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ in the controlling statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30, have been interpreted to permit removal if in the best interests of the child… We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests. More particularly, it does not appear that he considered the advantages of the move with respect to the emotional well-being of the family unit as a whole…”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: The court may modify parenting time to ensure it reflects the realities of the parties’ current circumstances and protects the child’s welfare.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses the judge’s authority to reduce and structure the father’s visitation time based on the circumstances and the children’s best interests. The appellate court affirms a modification from a more expansive temporary visitation schedule to a more limited final schedule, explicitly grounded in the realities of parental conflict and concerns about the children’s welfare. This aligns with the proposition that parenting time may be modified to reflect current circumstances and protect the child’s welfare.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order… ‘[T]he ‘best interests’ of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’”

Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).proposition: The court may modify parenting time to ensure it reflects the realities of the parties’ current circumstances and protects the child’s welfare.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with modification of alimony obligations upon the payor’s retirement and the possibility of retroactive modification of alimony arrears. It does not address custody, visitation, or parenting time, nor does it discuss modifying any parenting schedule to reflect current circumstances or to protect a child’s welfare. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the claimed parenting‑time proposition.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Here, Rudolph was successful in modifying the divorce judgment with respect to his alimony obligation, but he did not succeed in terminating that obligation.”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The court may modify parenting time to ensure it reflects the realities of the parties’ current circumstances and protects the child’s welfare.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion deals with standards for determining an initial custody award and emphasizes that custody decisions must be based on the child’s welfare and a weighing of all relevant factors. It does not address modification of parenting time or custody to reflect changed or current circumstances; rather, it remands for further findings because the original award may have been based on improper criteria. Therefore it does not provide authority for modifying parenting time to reflect current realities, even though it stresses the child’s welfare as the governing consideration.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: In light of the Defendant’s relocation and its direct adverse effects on the child’s rest, education, and emotional well‑being, justice requires modification of the parenting schedule.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion does not concern a post‑judgment modification based on a parent’s relocation and alleged adverse effects on the child. Instead, it addresses an initial custody determination between unmarried parents and discusses the “best interests of the child” standard and the statutory factors under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a). The Court does not hold that relocation and related impacts on rest, education, and emotional well‑being require modification of an existing parenting schedule, so it does not provide authority for the specific modification proposition stated.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 209C, § 10 (a), which was enacted in 1986, reflects this trend… The statute gives direction to the judge’s consideration of a child’s ‘best interests’ by ‘evincing a general intent on the part of the Legislature to maintain the bonds between the child and her caregiver.’ … The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child.”}
